description: Variant of shrub, possibly under Norse influence.

adjectives.description: scrub (comparative more scrub, superlative most scrub)

entries.meaning: Mean; dirty; contemptible; scrubby.
examples: How solitary, how scrub, does this town look!

entries.meaning: One who labors hard and lives meanly; a mean fellow.
examples: A sorry scrub, said Mr. High-mind.

entries.meaning: One who is incompetent or unable to complete easy tasks.
examples: What a scrub! Instead of washing the dishes she put the used food on her face!

entries.meaning: A thicket or jungle, often specified by the name of the prevailing plant

(US, stock breeding) One of the common livestock of a region of no particular breed or not of pure breed, especially when inferior in size, etc. Often used to refer to male animals unsuited for breeding.
Vegetation of inferior quality, though sometimes thick and impenetrable, growing in poor soil or in sand; also, brush.
One not on the first team of players; a substitute.
(obsolete, slang) Informal attire or dress code; morning dress

description: From Middle English scrobben (“groom a horse with a currycomb”); from Middle Dutch schrobben (“clean by scrubbing”).

entries.meaning: An instance of scrubbing.
A cancellation.
examples: Unacceptable winds aloft caused four scrubs and one hold; adverse weather caused a scrub;  […]

entries.meaning: A worn-out brush.
One who scrubs.
An exfoliant for the body.
(medicine, in the plural) Clothing worn while performing surgery.
(by extension, in the plural) Any medical uniform consisting of a short-sleeved shirt and pants (trousers).
examples: A man dressed as a lab tech, his blue scrubs startlingly pale against the vivid red and black chaos, moved into sight from behind the SUV. He carried an assault rifle.

verbs.description: scrub (third-person singular simple present scrubs, present participle scrubbing, simple past and past participle scrubbed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To rub hard; to wash with rubbing; usually, to rub with a wet brush, or with something coarse or rough, for the purpose of cleaning or brightening
(intransitive) To rub anything hard, especially with a wet brush; to scour
(intransitive, figuratively) To be diligent and penurious
examples: to scrub hard for a living

entries.meaning: (transitive) To call off a scheduled event; to cancel.
examples: Engineers had to scrub the satellite launch due to bad weather.

entries.meaning: (databases, transitive) To eliminate or to correct data from a set of records to bring it inline with other similar datasets
examples: The street segment data from the National Post Office will need to be scrubbed before it can be integrated into our system.

entries.meaning: (audio) To move a recording tape back and forth with a scrubbing motion to produce a scratching sound, or to do so by a similar use of a control on an editing system.
(audio, video) To maneuver the play position on a media editing system by using a scroll bar or touch-based interface.
